paper_abstract: In this new age of human-centered computing, human-computer interaction (HCI) must look to new technologies for building intuitive interfaces. Video is one such technology. Computer vision techniques could provide far richer interactivity than conventional devices. With the video input signal, systems could use large-scale, unencumbered motion from multiple concurrent users, leading to more direct, robust, and effective computing. The visual interaction cues paradigm uses a shared perceptual space between the user and the computer. Approaching the problem this way removes the need to globally track and model the user.
paper_title: A practical paradigm and platform for video-based human-computer interaction
